intro: Chassalia calamus, commonly known as the common chassalia, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring slender, hollow stems and compound leaves. Its small, yellowish flowers are arranged in umbels, a feature typical of the Apiaceae family. The roots and leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits.
